items.message: Sea spray overtopping is forecast along the coast as a result of high spring tides.  Forecast high water is 08:30 on 05/03/22 with a level of 6.30 mAOD and a Force 5 Northerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease for the 05/03/22 high tide at 20:45. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Saturday, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: This flood alert is no longer in force, as levels on the River Ouse are falling below levels of concern. There is no further significant rainfall expected over the coming days and we expect levels to continue to slowly fall towards normal. We will continue to monitor river levels. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This flood alert is no longer in force, as levels on the River Ouse are falling below levels of concern. There is no further significant rainfall expected over the coming days and we expect levels to continue to slowly fall towards normal. We will continue to monitor river levels. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels at the Shardlow and Willington river gauges have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.    The forecast is for predominantly dry conditions over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday 08/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Monday 07/03/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high but are now falling at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. There is no flooding at other gauge locations. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. We expect river levels to remain high until this evening, Sunday, 06/03/22. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Monday 07/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Thame following rainfall earlier in the week. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially close to the river around Dorchester-on-Thames, Thame and Stadhampton. We are expecting a mostly dry day with a couple of scattered showers this afternoon (Sunday 6th March). River levels are now stable but we expect them to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this afternoon, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides combined with high fluvial river levels will be at their highest between 23:30 Saturday, 05/03/22 and 00:30 Sunday, 06/03/22 and 12:00 and 13:00 Sunday, 06/03/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations affected; low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.5m to 3.7m 05/03/22 at 23:45 and 3.3m to 3.6m on 06/03/22 at 12:00, Gloucester 3.3m to 3.5m 05/03/22 at 23:30 and 3.4m to 3.6m 06/03/22 at 12:00. Flooding is not expected at other tidal gauge locations. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk at high tides.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.    
We continue to monitor the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please avoid contact with flood water.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island tomorrow morning the 6th March at 5:30 am and is forecast to reach approximately 5.00-5.10 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected at 6:00 pm tomorrow evening and is forecast to reach approximately 4.90-5.00 metres. The river could overtop banks and flood the very lowest lying land on Trowlock Island.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Thames Barrier is not currently forecast to close for the high tides tomorrow morning and evening. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high but steady at the Sutton Gault river gauge, and river levels are rising at the Welney Causeway river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Sunday 06/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Sunday, 06/03/2022. This information is correct as of 07:40 on Sunday 06 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 20 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 2 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. Due to uneven surface of the road, water may be deeper in places. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Sutton Gault river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Sunday 06/03/22. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Sunday, 06/03/2022. This information is correct as of 07:40 on Sunday 06 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 20 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the road, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 06/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.
River levels on the Chertsey Bourne are stable, but continue to remain high in some locations in Chertsey. Continued flooding of some low lying land and roads in isolated locations in Chertsey is still possible overnight tonight and into tomorrow, 06/03/22. However river levels are expected to start to fall slowly during the day tomorrow, so we may be able to remove this Flood Alert tomorrow. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels on the Lower River Loddon remain high but are falling slowly and the river is flowing within its banks. There may still be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding isn’t currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Flooding is no longer expected. 
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides at 5:15 pm today (05/03/22) and 5:30 am tomorrow, but flooding of low lying land, roads and footpaths from these high tides is no longer expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and will reissue this alert if necessary. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels are rising at the Welney Causeway river gauge following recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Sunday 06/03/2022.  We expect flooding to affect the A1101 Wash Road at Welney.   No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout today, Sunday 06/03/22. This information is correct as of 07:40 on Sunday 06 March. The causeway at Welney has approximately 2 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. This alert applies to WELNEY CAUSEWAY ONLY. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 06/03/2022, or as the situation changes.
